Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating Variability in the Frequency of Fire Use in the Archaeological Record

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This doctoral dissertation project will investigate the use of fire, an important adaptation in human prehistory, and its relationship to fluctuating environmental conditions. Burned stone artifacts will be quantified (frequencies) as measures of fire use in several stone artifact assemblages from Paleolithic archaeological sites selected from a wide range of temporal, geographic, and climatic conditions. Other evidence of fire use, such as hearths, is often qualitative (presence/absence) and therefore of limited utility in documenting the intensity or extent of fire use at these sites. The project will advance knowledge about human behavioral plasticity with respect to changing environments. It will also leverage available, but often neglected, data from museum collections, and will make these data accessible to a range of scholars through publications and databases. Public presentations about the findings will be made in museum settings to engage wider audiences, and background information and results of the project also will be shared through public archaeology podcasts and social media. Outreach activities will promote the participation of women and adult learners in scientific inquiry, and foster interest in archaeological and paleoanthropological research.<br/><br/>The frequency of burned stone artifacts will be compared across strata using three different sampling strategies (two types of counting methods, as well as weight) based on a size-grade distribution. Integrating the resulting data with other direct and geoarchaeological evidence of fire use will help to document the extent to which fire was used during the period of occupation associated with each cold and warm interval during the Paleolithic period. In addition, a controlled experiment using an ultra-low freezer will be conducted to assess the impact of the natural process of frost weathering on stone artifacts, to increase the level of accuracy and reliability in the identification of burned flints by distinguishing surface alterations that are caused by frosting exposures from those of burning. Petrographic and scanning electron microscopy, as well as Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy, will be used to detect macro- and microscopic alterations on the surface of experimentally frost-weathered artifacts. The results of this project will contribute to the field of Paleolithic archaeology by advancing sampling methods and experimental designs for the analysis of burned stone artifacts, as well as documenting burned artifacts from an extensive geographic range.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

NSF DDRIG BCS-2029098

 

            The start and frequency of fire use in Pleistocene Europe have been the subject of continuing debate among paleoanthropological researchers. Although fire use appears to be more frequent and central to many aspects of hominin life in the late Middle Pleistocene of Europe, it may not have been widespread in every geographic region and climatic context. Previous work on the pattern of fire use in southwestern France, based on quantifying the amount of burned lithics (stone artifacts) and animal bones within individual assemblages, revealed a noteworthy pattern?a lower frequency of fire use during cold periods and a higher frequency of fire use during warmer periods. Such a finding raised questions about whether all hominin populations in the late Middle and Late Pleistocene of Europe were dependent on fire in their behavioral adaptations. With NSF support, we investigated evidence for fire use in lithic collections from other Middle and Upper Paleolithic sites in Europe and southwest Asia. More specifically, we examined the extent of variability in the frequency of fire use by Neandertals and modern humans through quantifying the frequency of burned lithics.

            In the Paleolithic period, the absence of structured hearths (i.e., deliberate construction of hearth features, such as a shallow pit or a ring of stones) and the poor preservation of combustion features makes it difficult to accurately identify the evidence and extent of fire use in the depositional layers of a site. To overcome this limitation, we used the proportion of burned lithics as a proxy for fire presence. This approach is a quantitative rather than a simple measure of the presence or absence of fire use, and lithics are highly resistant to taphonomic destruction or alteration. Moreover, we determined whether there was an association between frequency of fire use and geoclimatic conditions at the selected Middle/Upper Paleolithic sites. This was accomplished by evaluating paleoclimate data based on the relative percentage of medium to large mammal species (based on %NISP [number of identified specimens] identified to the genus or species level) to characterize the climatic setting of each archaeological layer from each site.

            Our examination of the relationship between fire use and climatic conditions at each layer of the Middle Paleolithic sites supported a pattern first documented for southwestern France in which fire use was sporadic and lower in layers deposited during colder periods in comparison to layers marked by warmer adapted fauna (i.e., temperate and humid climatic conditions). Comparison of the results of Middle Paleolithic sites from other European regions to one Upper Paleolithic site from southwestern France and two Middle Paleolithic sites from the Levant (Mediterranean region of Southwest Asia) showed a different pattern. In this case, fire use frequency was more consistent and prevalent regardless of climatic variability, meaning that fire use did not follow any pattern related to climate, i.e., colder vs. warmer intervals. These findings suggested that environmental variables, such as climate and geography, influenced variability in fire use during the Late Pleistocene of Europe, although the mechanism(s) through which this operated are unclear and possibly variable by region (Abdolahzadeh et al. 2022).

            In addition to the analysis of lithic collections, we conducted a series of lithic taphonomic experiments, including heat and freeze-thaw weathering experiments, to identify some of the post-depositional features of fire and weathering exposure on lithic artifacts. The goal of the heat experiments was to characterize the intensity and duration of fire-related activities by Middle Paleolithic hunter-gatherers through the analysis of lithic fracture attributes caused by heat. The results revealed evidence for short-term fire events by mobile hunter-gatherer involving high temperature fires with the close proximity of lithics to the heat source that intensified heat fracture regardless of the duration of heating (Abdolahzadeh et al. 2023). The freeze-thaw weathering experiment provided new data about frost-weathered lithic artifacts that distinguished thermally altered lithic artifacts from frost-weathered ones. Except for color change, frost-weathered flints showed no surface alteration features resembling thermal-stress features, such as potlids and thermal breakage.

            The results of our NSF-funded research award open new avenues for future studies of pyrotechnology use among hominin species. For example, variables such as differences in net primary productivity, increased access to natural fires (e.g., caused by lightning strikes), or the costs and benefits of fire use during different geoclimatic conditions from a wider spatio-temporal context, can be tested as possible explanatory mechanisms for variability in fire use by hominins. Overall, our findings indicate that the frequency of fire making and use among archaic humans varied considerably. This finding raises important questions about their behavioral adaptations in colder regions and/or colder climatic conditions over the past 300-500 thousand years.
